articles.title: Harvard vs Trump: millions in grant money begin trickling back to scientists
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03036-1A court ruling declared the Trump administration’s termination of the university’s research funding illegal.
articles.content:
Update: Soon after Nature posted this story, some US$11 million from the US National Science Foundation began flowing back to Harvard. The Harvard Crimson also reported that $46 million in funds from the US National Institutes of Health are now going to the university. This afternoon, in a joint status update before a judge, both Harvard and the US government asked for more time to “work through implementation issues” of complying fully with the court order.

Harvard University scored a victory in court two weeks ago, when a US judge ruled that its research grants should be reinstated and its funding unfrozen. But the administration of Republican President Donald Trump does not yet seem to be fully complying with the court order.

Harvard vs Trump: what this epic battle means for science

In May, Trump’s team terminated roughly 1,000 grants awarded to Harvard worth more than US$2.8 billion, citing the institution’s alleged failure to protect its students from antisemitism. An internal e-mail sent on 12 September to staff members at Harvard, which is based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, noted that the university had “received indications” that most of its grants from the US National Institutes of Health (NIH) — a massive funder of biomedical research — had been restored. But researchers have told Nature that they still aren’t receiving the money.

A Harvard spokesperson confirms that “payments have not been restored”, meaning that although the NIH is reactivating grants, the payment system — which operates separately — is still blocked. When asked about the freeze on funding, the NIH declined to comment on the record.

The Trump administration has said it will appeal the Harvard court decision. The case is likely to end up before the US Supreme Court, says David Super, a specialist in administrative law at Georgetown University in Washington DC.

Hong Kong universities woo Harvard international students targeted by Trump

But in the meantime, legal scholars have told Nature that the government should, by this point, have unfrozen Harvard’s money. “You should comply with a court order as rapidly as you reasonably could,” Super says.

At least one US funding agency seems to be restoring funding, however. On Wednesday, the US National Science Foundation (NSF), which financially supports about 25% of basic US academic research, sent an e-mail informing Harvard that its grants have been reinstated and its funding unfrozen. “You may begin drawing funds,” the e-mail states. (The NSF uses a different payment system from the NIH’s.)

One affected researcher is Julia Mundy, a condensed-matter physicist at Harvard who lost a prestigious NSF award for early-career scientists. “This is a positive step,” she says. “But we also still feel a lot of uncertainty, because it doesn’t feel that everything is resolved yet.”

Harvard vs Trump

Harvard has been central to the Trump administration’s campaign to reshape US higher education, which it has said is too left-leaning. In April, government officials froze federal funds to the institution — the wealthiest in the world — and demanded, among other things, that it eliminate diversity, equity and inclusion programmes and achieve “viewpoint diversity” in student admissions and the hiring of faculty members.

Two students work in the laboratory of Julia Mundy, a condensed-matter physicist at Harvard who studies atomically-thin materials.Credit: Charles Brooks

When Harvard refused to fully comply, the Trump team terminated the institution’s federal grants across 19 US agencies, alleging that the university allowed “pervasive race discrimination and anti-Semitic harassment”. The school sued, and on 3 September, Massachusetts district court judge Allison Burroughs ruled that the grant terminations were illegal because they violated Harvard’s constitutional right to free speech.

“There is, in reality, little connection between the research affected by the grant terminations and antisemitism,” Burroughs, who was appointed by former Democratic president Barack Obama, wrote in her decision. She called the claim of antisemitism a “smokescreen” and cited Trump’s social-media posts, including one saying that Harvard is “hiring almost all woke, Radical Left, idiots and ‘birdbrains’ who are only capable of teaching FAILURE to students”.

Court conundrum

The bottleneck in which Harvard’s NIH grants are now held up is a system called Payment Management Services (PMS), which processes requests for withdrawing money from grants and is run by the NIH’s parent agency, the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). When asked why grant payments aren’t flowing, PMS directed Nature to submit a Freedom of Information Act request to the HHS.

Harvard researchers devastated as Trump team cuts nearly 1,000 grants

Although it can take time to resume payments, it should not take two weeks, Super says. It seems that the government could be violating the court’s order by only partially complying, he adds.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant legal victory restoring millions in research funding to Harvard after an illegal termination by the Trump administration, upholding constitutional rights and supporting scientific research. This has broad implications for academic freedom, free speech, and the protection of research funding, benefiting the wider scientific community and society.
articles.personality_title: Court orders return of millions in research funds to Harvard after illegal freeze
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2025, the Trump administration stopped nearly 1,000 research grants to Harvard University, totaling over $2.8 billion. They claimed the university failed to protect students from antisemitism. Harvard disagreed and took the case to court.

**What happened** – A judge ruled that the government’s freeze on Harvard’s research funding was illegal and ordered the money to be returned. Soon after, $11 million from the National Science Foundation and $46 million from the National Institutes of Health began flowing back to Harvard. However, some funding systems are still slow to release payments.

**Impact** – This ruling protects Harvard’s right to free speech and academic freedom. It also ensures that important scientific research can continue without political interference. Researchers who lost funding are now able to restart their projects, which benefits scientific progress.

**What’s next step** – The Trump administration plans to appeal the decision, so the case might reach the US Supreme Court. Meanwhile, Harvard and the government are working on fixing technical issues to fully restore all funding.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A court decision has reversed an illegal funding freeze, allowing millions in research grants to return to Harvard and supporting the continuation of vital scientific work.

articles.personality_title_es: Un tribunal ordena la devolución de millones en fondos de investigación a Harvard tras una congelación ilegal
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2025, la administración Trump detuvo casi 1,000 subvenciones de investigación a la Universidad de Harvard, por un total de más de 2.8 mil millones de dólares, alegando que la universidad no protegía a sus estudiantes contra el antisemitismo. Harvard impugnó esta decisión en la corte.

Sin embargo, algunos sistemas de pago aún tardan en liberar los fondos.

También asegura que la investigación científica importante pueda continuar sin interferencias políticas. Los investigadores afectados pueden reanudar sus proyectos, lo que ayuda al avance científico.

**Próximo paso** – La administración Trump planea apelar la decisión, por lo que el caso podría llegar a la Corte Suprema de Estados Unidos. Mientras tanto, Harvard y el gobierno trabajan para resolver problemas técnicos y restaurar por completo los fondos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Una decisión judicial revierte una congelación ilegal de fondos, permitiendo que millones en subvenciones de investigación regresen a Harvard y apoyando la continuidad del trabajo científico vital.

articles.title: From crisis messaging to community voices: Reimagining aid communication in Somalia
articles.summary: Visibility-driven fundraising is crucial for sustaining life-saving interventions, but when storytelling focuses solely on immediate impact, it may undermine longer-term capacity building.
articles.content:
Most aid and development agencies rely on marketing and communication frameworks to fundraise and address pressing global challenges, including the prevention of humanitarian crises. Yet many of these strategies fall short because they do not sufficiently engage in co-creation with the affected communities. They also struggle to withstand shrinking funding spaces and sudden shifts in donor policies. I argue that aid agencies must invest more in participatory communication as a sustainable approach that empowers communities beyond the limits of emergency relief.

In 2017, humanitarian partners, including the United Nations (UN), International Non-Governmental Organisations(INGOs), the Federal Government of Somalia, and international donors, mobilized around USD 1.3 billion in aid, then the largest response in the country’s history. Five years later, in 2022, that figure rose to USD 2.1 billion, as drought once again created a risk for widespread famine. But in 2025, funding dropped sharply, with less than a quarter of the required amount received.

The humanitarian sector is also under immense financial strain. During recent funding cuts by the United States, major NGOs announced mass staff layoffs, underscoring the volatility of relying on a small pool of donors. At the same time, the needs in Somalia are immense. Today, 1.8 million children under five suffer from acute malnutrition, including nearly 470,000 with severe acute malnutrition. These numbers are rising as conflict, drought, and dwindling funds converge.

The contrast is clear: While international headlines and appeals continue to rely on powerful images and testimonies that resonate with global audiences, local communities are too often left without a strong voice in shaping the kind of support they receive or how it is delivered.

Beyond powerful images

What often goes under the radar is the model of communication that aid agencies use. Most stories are built around emotional visuals, beneficiary testimonies, and simplified impact narratives designed to attract donor support. Somalia is a striking example of this. In 2022, ABC News travelled to report on the drought-induced humanitarian crisis in Somalia and captured the story of Maliaka (not her real name), a severely malnourished child treated at a health facility supported by USAID. The story was powerful: it moved audiences, generated funds, and expanded relief efforts. Yet two years later, following USAID’s withdrawal, the same health facility is at risk of running out of therapeutic food.

Also, Somalia’s government still depends on external grants for around half of its budget. This means shifting donor policies and shrinking aid funds can quickly reverse progress. Success stories can collapse into failures as schools and health facilities close once projects end. Donor-focused communication is essential but insufficient.

Blurred lines

The persuasive communication model sustains fundraising; however, its limitations are clear in contexts like Somalia, where crises recur and donor fatigue is real.

A more participatory communication model that empowers communities and allows them to guide the conversation would strengthen ownership and resilience. This means actively involving community members in decision-making, programme design, and evaluation. Most importantly, it requires that all communication and media products that are circulated by aid and development agencies to the national audience should follow a participatory communication approach. For example, consulting families about the support they need, engaging local health workers in planning, involving community leaders in monitoring outcomes, and tailoring communication products for the needs of local programme participants.

While some of this exists in current programmes, community participation is often consultative rather than empowering. Agencies may gather feedback, but decisions on resources and interventions remain externally driven. Communities remain participants in name, rarely gaining the authority to shape the projects that affect their lives.

From visibility to empowerment

There is a blurred line between visibility, fundraising, and empowerment. Donor-driven storytelling prioritizes visibility to donor markets, often extending the same narratives to national audiences without adapting them. This risks overlooking local perspectives and results in less effective engagement. Visibility-driven fundraising is crucial for sustaining life-saving interventions, but when storytelling focuses solely on immediate impact, it may undermine longer-term capacity building.

Somalia offers a few exceptions. One notable example is the United Nations’ Tubta Nabada (Path to Peace) radio magazine show. Broadcast three times a week in partnership with local media, it brings together communities, civil society, and government representatives to discuss peace, security, and development. It demonstrates a participatory communication model that goes beyond fundraising. However, little public data exists on its impact, underscoring the need for more rigorous evaluation of participatory communication approaches.

Similarly, in 2023, the Save the Children Somalia program launched a child-focused podcast that follows a similar communication model to Tubta Nabada.

What needs to happen.

Somalia’s recurring crises highlight the fragility of aid systems that rely too heavily on donor-driven communication models. Despite the success of humanitarian responses in 2017 and 2022, communities still face challenges posed by extreme weather conditions like droughts and floods. The need to shift from the current approach is clearly demonstrated by the current humanitarian crisis amid shrinking donor funds and the policy shifts that led to the closure of USAID.

While visibility and fundraising remain essential to sustain life-saving interventions, they cannot substitute for genuine community empowerment. Aid agencies need to embed participatory communication into the heart of their strategies as a core practice. This means giving communities real authority in shaping stories, setting priorities, and evaluating outcomes. In an era of shrinking funds and shifting donor priorities, only communication that empowers communities can build the trust, resilience, and ownership necessary for sustainable change.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the need for a shift in humanitarian aid communication in Somalia towards participatory models that empower local communities, which can lead to more sustainable and effective aid outcomes. It addresses a significant issue affecting millions and proposes a meaningful change that could improve the quality and impact of aid, fostering community ownership and resilience beyond immediate crisis relief.
articles.personality_title: New ways to share stories in Somalia aim to empower communities
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Somalia faces repeated crises like drought and conflict, causing hunger and hardship. Aid agencies raise money by sharing powerful stories, but often these stories focus on quick fixes and don’t include the voices of the people affected.

**What happened** – Aid groups and the Somali government have raised billions to help during emergencies, like in 2017 and 2022. However, funding dropped sharply in 2025, forcing cuts in aid. Many stories used to get support show emotional images but don’t always involve local people in deciding how help is given. Some efforts, like a radio show and a podcast, now invite communities to join discussions about peace and support.

**Impact** – This shows that when local people help shape stories and aid plans, the support fits their real needs better and lasts longer. Relying only on donor-focused stories can cause projects to fail once funding ends. Giving communities a stronger voice helps build trust and makes aid more effective during ongoing crises.

**What's next step** – Aid agencies are encouraged to change how they communicate by involving community members in telling their own stories and deciding what help they need. This means moving from just fundraising stories to sharing real experiences and ideas from the people affected. Doing this could improve how aid works, even when money is tight.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Helping communities in Somalia tell their own stories can make aid more lasting and better suited to their needs during tough times.
articles.personality_title_fr: De nouvelles façons de raconter en Somalie pour donner plus de pouvoir aux communautés
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Somalie fait face à des crises répétées comme la sécheresse et les conflits, provoquant la faim et des difficultés. Les agences d’aide collectent des fonds en partageant des histoires fortes, mais ces récits se concentrent souvent sur des solutions rapides sans inclure les voix des personnes concernées.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Les groupes d’aide et le gouvernement somalien ont levé des milliards pour aider lors des urgences, comme en 2017 et 2022. Cependant, les financements ont chuté fortement en 2025, provoquant des réductions d’aide. Beaucoup d’histoires utilisées pour obtenir du soutien montrent des images émouvantes, mais n’impliquent pas toujours les habitants dans la décision de l’aide à apporter. Certaines initiatives, comme une émission de radio et un podcast, invitent désormais les communautés à discuter de la paix et du soutien.

**Impact** – Cela montre que lorsque les habitants participent à la création des histoires et des plans d’aide, le soutien répond mieux à leurs vrais besoins et dure plus longtemps. Se fier uniquement aux récits pour les donateurs peut faire échouer les projets quand les financements s’arrêtent. Donner plus de pouvoir aux communautés aide à construire la confiance et rend l’aide plus efficace face aux crises répétées.

**Prochaine étape** – Les agences d’aide sont encouragées à changer leur communication en impliquant les membres des communautés pour raconter leurs propres histoires et décider de l’aide nécessaire. Il s’agit de passer des récits pour collecter des fonds à un partage d’expériences et d’idées réelles des personnes concernées. Cela pourrait améliorer l’aide, même en cas de budget serré.

**Une phrase clé** – Permettre aux communautés somaliennes de raconter leurs propres histoires peut rendre l’aide plus durable et mieux adaptée à leurs besoins en période difficile.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevas formas de contar historias en Somalia buscan empoderar a las comunidades
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Somalia enfrenta crisis repetidas como sequías y conflictos, causando hambre y dificultades. Las agencias de ayuda recaudan fondos compartiendo historias impactantes, pero a menudo se enfocan en soluciones rápidas sin incluir las voces de las personas afectadas.

**Qué pasó** – Grupos de ayuda y el gobierno somalí han recaudado miles de millones para emergencias, como en 2017 y 2022. Sin embargo, en 2025 la financiación cayó drásticamente, provocando recortes en la ayuda. Muchas historias usadas para conseguir apoyo muestran imágenes emotivas, pero no siempre involucran a las comunidades en las decisiones sobre la ayuda. Algunas iniciativas, como un programa de radio y un podcast, ahora invitan a las comunidades a participar en discusiones sobre paz y apoyo.

**Impacto** – Esto demuestra que cuando las personas ayudan a crear las historias y los planes de ayuda, el apoyo se adapta mejor a sus necesidades reales y dura más tiempo. Depender solo de historias para donantes puede hacer que los proyectos fracasen cuando se acaba la financiación. Darles una voz más fuerte a las comunidades ayuda a construir confianza y hace que la ayuda sea más efectiva durante crisis continuas.

**Próximo paso** – Se anima a las agencias de ayuda a cambiar su forma de comunicar involucrando a los miembros de la comunidad para contar sus propias historias y decidir qué ayuda necesitan. Esto significa pasar de historias solo para recaudar fondos a compartir experiencias e ideas reales de las personas afectadas. Esto podría mejorar la ayuda incluso cuando el dinero es limitado.

**Una frase clave** – Ayudar a las comunidades en Somalia a contar sus propias historias puede hacer que la ayuda sea más duradera y mejor adaptada a sus necesidades en tiempos difíciles.
